Students will begin to trickle back into the classrooms after leaving abruptly mid-March. The first students to get back inside our school buildings will be the students whose last names begin with A-K. 2) Wear a mask! Masks are mandatory.
3) Bring a bottle of water to school with you.
4) Know where you will be dropped off in the morning and picked up in the afternoon. (https://bit.ly/3fMpuf9)

A special thank you to staff, parents, and students for sharing your enthusiasm to start school this year in the safest way possible -- wear your mask, social distance, and wash your hands frequently! https://bit.ly/Tcusd2HW

post_text: Mary Bassett, a paraprofessional at Triad Middle School, is retiring after 15 years of service in the Triad District. Mrs. Bassett has taken on instructional responsibilities inside the classroom and as well as helping students navigate through the unstructured parts of the school day. Mrs. Bassett is known for liking structure just like when she reminds everyone that Wednesday is “hump day.” And the students are going to miss her morning “hellos” as she stationed herself outside the library to greet each student every morning. Luckily, the office captured her most memorable moment on video not long ago, something she will always be remembered for - the day she thought she could fill the secretary’s chair but quickly found out that it is hard to fill someone else’s “chair” just like it will be hard to find someone who can fill Mrs. Bassett’s “chair” next year. We wish Mrs. Bassett a relaxing, fun-filled retirement. Congratulations, Mary!

post_text: Cindy Kline, 6th grade Special Education Teacher, is retiring after 20 years of service in the Triad District. Mrs. Kline received her Bachelor's Degree from Indiana University and her Master's Degree from Rockford University. During her career, Mrs. Kline’s experiences included teaching birth to age-five children, teaching English as a second language, and teaching adult living skills. At Triad, Mrs. Kline enjoyed helping her colleagues when she wasn’t teaching. For six years, she served as the Triad Education Association President and for several years she coordinated grade-level events - events that she and her students will always remember. In the future, Mrs. Kline would love to take spontaneous trips, but she is content with staying home until it is safe to travel. She can count on her grandkids to keep her busy in the meantime. We wish Mrs. Kline a safe, relaxing, and fun-filled retirement. Congratulations, Cindy!

post_text: Julie Reising, 1st Grade Teacher in the Triad District, is retiring after 33 years of service all at Triad. Mrs. Reising attended the University of Illinois where she studied and was trained in brain research relating to methodologies used in teaching young children. Throughout her career, she dedicated a tremendous amount of time working on committees, mentoring new teachers and continuing her own learning. She has served on almost every elementary committee formed and was never shy about sharing her experiences, knowledge and opinions, which was a benefit to all. Mrs. Reising is also known for filling her classroom full of stuff that first-graders loved to be immersed in - books, games, posters and puppets. Without a doubt, Mrs. Reising’s retirement will be filled with family responsibilities, travel to see her kids and projects around the house, because we all know she never stops - she is an “all-in” teacher and person - from morning till night. Congratulations, Julie!!

September 12, 2019 at 5:03 PM ·

Today the staff and students at the Silver Creek Elementary School conducted an intruder drill. Several Troy Police Officers assisted the staff and School Resource Officer Jader during the drill. The following times and actions were documented during the drill.

2:00 p.m.
Intruder drill announced.

2:01 p.m.
ALL classrooms were locked down and all students were moved out of view from the hallway.

2:06 p.m.
The evacuation drill began.

2:14 p.m.
All students were evacuated out of the building and moved to their designated safe zones. Additionally 100% of all 750 students were accounted for by use of the CrisisGo app. This app. is used by all teachers and staff within the entire Triad School District as part of their safety plan.

In 1 minute, all classrooms were locked down and students moved to a safe location within the room.

In 8 minutes 750 students were evacuated out of the school and 100% accounted for!

What an absolute incredible job done by all of the teachers staff and students! Well done!!!

The Illinois Department of Transportation announced that US Route 40 from Rustic Lane to Triad Lane east of Troy in Madison County will be intermittently restricted to one lane during daylight hours beginning Thursday, August 2, 2018, weather permitting.

Two-way traffic will be maintained using flaggers. This work is required to do widening for upcoming bridge repair work. Starting Wednesday, August 8, 2018, the same location will again be restricted to one lane, weather permitting. Two-way traffic will be maintained using temporary traffic signals. This work is necessary to do repair work on the Silver Creek bridge.

This restriction is expected to be removed by mid-September of this year. The above two restrictions are part of a larger project, which includes resurfacing US Route 40 from Bethany Lane to the IL 4 ramps.

Delays should be expected and parents are encouraged to use school bus transportation to Triad Schools along Route 40 to assist in minimizing traffic and delays.
